title: Legendary Patriots kicker Adam Vinatieri elected to Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Adam Vinatieri elected to Pro Football Hall of Fame during NFL Honors ceremony, recognized for record-setting career.
Vinatieri, NFL all-time scoring leader with 2,673 points, played 24 seasons with the Patriots and Colts.
Vinatieri joins Morten Andersen and Jan Stenerud as the third kicker in Pro Football Hall of Fame history.

title: Drake Maye loses MVP race to Matthew Stafford by razor-thin margin
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye finished second in MVP voting with 361 points, narrowly behind Matthew Stafford's 366 points.
Matthew Stafford led the league in passing yards (4,707) and touchdowns (46), earning him NFL MVP over Maye.
Drake Maye led the Patriots to a 14-3 record and their first AFC East title since 2019.

title: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel was named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year at the NFL Honors ceremony.
Vrabel led the New England Patriots to a 17-3 record and a Super Bowl LX appearance.
This is Vrabel's second Coach of the Year award, previously winning with the Tennessee Titans in 2021.

title: Unlike Tom Brady, Tedy Bruschi has a dog in the Patriots-Seahawks fight
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tedy Bruschi openly supports the Patriots over the Seahawks in Super Bowl LX, unlike Tom Brady's neutral stance.
Bruschi's allegiance is influenced by his friendship with Patriots coach Mike Vrabel and team performance.
He compares the current Patriots team to the franchiseâ€™s first championship team, highlighting their defensive strengths.

title: Pedestrian struck by police cruiser at UMass Lowell, officials say
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A police cruiser struck a pedestrian near McGauvran Center on UMass Lowell's South Campus Thursday evening.
The incident occurred at the intersection of Wilder and Bachelder streets around 6:30 p.m., according to Lowell police.
UMass Lowell and Massachusetts State Police are investigating; counseling is offered to affected community members.

title: New Bedford police investigate after man goes missing, drowns in harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Jason Vasquez, 51, was found dead in New Bedford Harbor on January 31, three days after he went missing.
Vasquez was last seen after visiting a local adult establishment and worked at New Bedford Shipyard and Shoreline.
Police found Vasquez's body near his ship, and an investigation into his drowning is underway by local and state police.

title: Cambridge brewery workers plan to unionize, file for election
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Employees at Lamplighter Brewing Co. in Cambridge filed for a union election with UFCW Local 1445.
The union represents workers in industries like retail and food processing, including 11,000 workers in Massachusetts.
Lamplighter staff seek unionization to ensure their perspectives are considered in the evolving brewery industry.

title: Patriots OC Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year at NFL Honors ceremony in San Francisco.
Patriots' offense improved from third-worst to second-best in scoring under McDaniels, averaging 28.8 points per game.
McDaniels, on his third stint with the Patriots, avoids future head coaching speculation, focuses on current role.

title: Patriots, Seahawks both have defensive starters missing from practice
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Robert Spillane was limited in practice; Harold Landry and Seahawks' Nick Emmanwori did not participate due to injuries.
Landry missed practice due to a knee injury, impacting his performance throughout the season, including missed regular season games.
Seahawks' Emmanwori suffered an ankle injury, but coach Macdonald expects him to participate in walkthroughs and possibly play.

title: NY man allegedly stole $325K in seafood from Worcester warehouse in 1 of several heists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Romoy Forbes, 31, from Deer Park, NY, faces conspiracy charges for allegedly stealing $325K in frozen snow crab from a Worcester warehouse.
Forbes is accused of hacking trucking carrier emails to steal blueberries, frozen snow crabs, and $400K worth of designer cologne.
If convicted, Forbes could face up to 15 years in prison and $500,000 in fines for interstate transportation and conspiracy charges.
